data.text:
How can we contribute to tackling climate change? What's our role as a central bank and supervisor? 

Tune in to the latest episode of #TheECBPodcast with Executive Board members @Isabel_Schnabel and @FrankElderson and our new host @KatieRanger_
https://t.co/GcwD4Rfr3Y https://t.co/hDw4gu46JH

The working group on euro risk-free rates will move its secretariat from the ECB to ESMA. It also published recommendations to help the EURIBOR users to comply with fallback obligations. Want to know more? 
Press release 
https://t.co/vxVnwZmb7X
Website 
https://t.co/U0ZnHrdJOI https://t.co/ZeKfbwf7eb

Panetta: All financial activities should be aligned with climate objectives, including crypto-assets. Bitcoin alone consumes more electricity than the Netherlands. Controlling and limiting the environmental impact of crypto-assets should be part of the global discussion 3/3

Panetta: If an activity is considered sustainable in one country but unsustainable in another, there cannot be a truly global sustainable finance market. That's why we need international disclosure standards and principles to categorise sustainable activities 2/3

(THREAD) We need global standards to combat greenwashing and improve transparency in sustainable finance, writes Executive Board member Fabio Panetta in #TheECBBlog. Inconsistent approaches risk leading to fragmented markets and lowering standards https://t.co/M52UgKcMUd 1/3 https://t.co/7SYuhfeMX4

While the economy will be growing quickly, the euro area will need until around this time next year to get back to pre-pandemic levels, Chief Economist Philip R. Lane tells @lemondefr.

Full interview
EN https://t.co/t6kYbo0So2  
FR https://t.co/kr8ljLPUVb https://t.co/aZDQjv3AEE
Working Paper: Can central bank communication help to stabilise inflation expectations? https://t.co/SpXqPL85MS
Find out how we’re working together for the #FutureofEurope with @Europarl_EN, @EUCouncil, @EU_Commission, @EIB, @EU_CoR, @EU_EESC, @eu_eeas and other EU institutions.

Happy Europe Day! 🇪🇺
Check out the ongoing initiatives of the EU institutions, including our #EuropeDay quiz here https://t.co/JUvqGtyLuG https://t.co/ZS4IiKypOS

I want to contribute to European cooperation, Executive Board member @FrankElderson tells @FD_Nieuws in a personal interview about his career as a lawyer and how he went from working in EU competition law to shaping our monetary union @DNB_NL and the ECB https://t.co/M2Lj6E4Qov https://t.co/Yl0oqQe2cq
Working Paper: Globalisation and the efficiency-equity trade-off https://t.co/mYWJh1hUdc
Working Paper: Market failures in market-based finance https://t.co/sx5PmHPJnP

Most banks now broadly meet our expectations on managing credit risk, but 40% still have big gaps, says Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria. If banks move early to recognise issues and engage with customers, we have the tools to deal with the problem https://t.co/Q03EXqBuoQ https://t.co/VDFcTUpRl9

Lagarde:

2⃣ A Green CMU can help transform our economies as structural changes speed up around us. We must redirect activity towards the green and digital sectors as quickly as possible to raise Europe’s growth potential

3/3

Lagarde: A Green CMU could help address two wider challenges we face today:

1⃣ It can make our monetary union more resilient to cyclical shocks. To achieve this, we must do better at reducing risks and sharing them across countries

2/3

(THREAD) The green transition offers a unique opportunity to build a truly European capital market that transcends national borders, says President Christine @Lagarde. It could be called a green capital markets union (CMU).

Read her full remarks https://t.co/pAU1oqKqgu 1/3 https://t.co/Pk7wm165CT
Euro area bank interest rate statistics (March 2021) https://t.co/GqiH7VTFnG

Energy prices pushed up euro area headline inflation in recent months, driven by oil prices, tax changes & environmental surcharges. This temporary rise in energy inflation is expected to be followed by a decline in early 2022. Read more https://t.co/sYFke7szcz #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/ULch2NM0B0

The latest Economic Bulletin is out! The Bulletin presents the economic and monetary information which forms the basis for our policy decisions. Read more https://t.co/5Ky1x7dwHa https://t.co/9WPBhaikab

Watch live from 15:00 CET: Chief Economist Philip R. Lane participates in an @OMFIF panel discussing the ECB’s strategy review and current challenges for monetary policy.

Register here https://t.co/z3P7qkPx94 https://t.co/lnkI3wy4xp

If the financial markets are the only segment repricing higher longer-term inflation expectations, the resulting tightening of financing conditions would limit expenditure and actually prevent price pressures from building up. Read more https://t.co/9Ycx4n2e9a #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/CbpJLOPRTy

Households finance government debt, in the euro area especially via pension and investment funds and insurance corporations. Experiences outside Europe show that this role could become even more important. Read more https://t.co/ca5GnEL8lB #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/aXO2JUzq0a

Chief Economist Philip R. Lane discusses the resilience of the euro in its first 20 years in the latest issue of the Journal of Economic Perspectives. In particular, he examines lessons learned from the crisis period of 2008 to 2013.
 
Read his article https://t.co/7hOv0Rsd9B https://t.co/6aIBLaKR58

Applications are now open for our Women in Economics Scholarship, which offers a grant and ECB study visit to master's students.

If you are an EU national with excellent undergraduate grades, you may be eligible. Learn more and apply here https://t.co/U0JWSmHU8b https://t.co/Uc7cCfsYo1

Brexit and the resulting drop in UK demand for goods from the euro area have caused a sizeable drag on exports. Future UK trade deficits with the euro area will require net financial inflows to remain sustainable. Read more https://t.co/lnuM0o80EC #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/KeVzvj8qq8

We were pleased to virtually meet members of the European Parliament’s Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs today.

MEPs play a critical role in ensuring our accountability. https://t.co/kdq8Iwzquy

Enria: The Basel regulatory reforms enabled banks to tackle this pandemic shock of an unprecedented scale. Overall, banks were able to fall back on much stronger capital positions and liquidity buffers than in the past 3/3

Enria: There are very low phase-in costs associated with the last stretch of implementing Basel III reforms. These short-term costs are fully compensated by a more resilient banking sector in the long run 2/3

(THREAD) We are on the last leg of a long banking regulation marathon of more than 40 years, says Supervisory Chair Andrea Enria. Let’s not jeopardise this effort: Any delay now would slow down necessary adjustments in the banking sector https://t.co/D51ElPff9Q 1/3 https://t.co/0HfmLLChSR
Working Paper: Combining Bayesian VARs with survey density forecasts - Does it pay off? https://t.co/mpF7dtCW7j
Check out other initiatives from @Europarl_EN, @EUCouncil, @EU_Commission, @EIB, @EU_CoR, @EU_EESC, and @eu_eeas at the Europe Day hub in all EU languages https://t.co/JUvqGtyLuG

#EuropeDay is just around the corner! 
How much do you really know about Europe and the euro? Test your knowledge by taking our #EuropeDay quiz on QuizDuel by 23 May and win an iPad! Find out how to participate https://t.co/fUQePgdl5e https://t.co/RplJ5jdzmM

The rapid recovery in activity and trade is the main driver of the recent surge in shipping costs. This demand is also causing global supply shortages and bottlenecks as production capacity adjusts only slowly. Read more https://t.co/Vysgyhe6x5 #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/tzabbClo6T

Liquidity usage in TARGET2 has changed considerably since 2008, mainly due to the high level of central bank reserves. The sovereign debt crisis, asset purchase programmes and our recent measures in the pandemic all played a role https://t.co/hyWFQdFU8A #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/vJSWEVIy8u

De Guindos: We need to complete the monetary union. And we need to complete the banking union with the European deposit insurance scheme, we need to work on the capital markets union and to converge towards a European instrument to pursue a common fiscal policy.

The impact of the pandemic varies across the euro area, says Vice-President Luis de Guindos. That’s why NextGenerationEU is so important: more funds are earmarked for the countries hardest hit by the pandemic
https://t.co/SWbSJ5m9wP IT
https://t.co/up9w52OABq EN https://t.co/5cXQghsXIA

We are pleased to welcome Irene Heemskerk as head of our new climate change centre. She will take up her position as of 15 June 2021. We wish her all the best in this important role! https://t.co/S8wdgycGe4 https://t.co/XASjmyNLir https://t.co/V9AiDLWMNm

We are at an inflection point, Chief Economist Philip R. Lane tells @dise_tv.

The initial weeks of 2021 have been very tough but, as vaccination programmes are rolled out and the service sector reopens, a rebound from the worst of the pandemic will start https://t.co/cR1tNCz6v4 https://t.co/bH93ttI29B
Letter from Andrea Enria, Chair of the Supervisory Board, to Mr Zanni, Ms Donato, Mr Grant and Mr Rinaldi, MEPs, on credit risk https://t.co/scZURlLRjv (EN) https://t.co/T0yOgmRQ2t (IT)

Climate change creates material risks for banks. As supervisor, it is our job to ensure banks address these risks adequately and proactively, Supervisory Board Vice-Chair @FrankElderson explains at a conference held by @EBRD and @HNB_HR. Read more https://t.co/fqd56r5JLm https://t.co/bQ8YCiV8zb
Euro area economic and financial developments by institutional sector (Q4 2020) https://t.co/obpjDinfSO

Our 2020 Money Market study is available! It shows among other things that our monetary policy measures were successful in reducing rate disruptions in some money market segments, which returned to normal functioning by mid-2020. Find out more https://t.co/2okdMHhzUc https://t.co/nGEUNg5VDm
How did euro area bank lending and money supply evolve in March? How do they compare with February’s figures? Find out more in the press release https://t.co/toV6cuEe2j https://t.co/OuLKapwGfa

⚡️Missed our live Twitter Q&A with Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel? Catch up here! #AskECB
https://t.co/cazq8SOZQ5
https://t.co/IVAYw8FKqp
https://t.co/Wz4tVuC2GA
Time to wrap up. Thanks a lot for your questions – I really enjoyed the chat and look forward to doing this again soon. Take care! #AskECB https://t.co/dFaVhAr8E1

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: Your initiative is very welcome. We have conducted numerous listening events ourselves and will continue to do so. The feedback from citizens is one important input into our strategy review. #AskECB https://t.co/lFSvZsoVkn

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: We have indeed involved academics in our strategy review process through an Academic Roundtable and through our annual ECB Forum on Central Banking (“Sintra”). We have also had numerous informal exchanges with economists from all over the world. #AskECB https://t.co/0GMExGu23r

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: Most economists agree that deflation has worse economic consequences than small positive inflation. It leads to a deepening of recessions when agents postpone consumption & investment in expectation of falling prices resulting in a deflationary spiral. #AskECB https://t.co/egFRGEpfrc
You can find out more about changes in consumption patterns during the COVID-19 pandemic in our Economic Bulletin: https://t.co/HifHNSBYBj

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: Food accounts for a large share of the consumption basket. Spikes in food inflation thus push up overall inflation. HICP weights are adjusted on an annual basis by Eurostat to reflect shifts in consumption. We look through short-term volatility. #AskECB https://t.co/uall0Xr3L1

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: Our monetary policy is guided by our price stability objective. Over the past decades, the relationship between monetary aggregates and inflation has weakened. Therefore, our monetary analysis has put a stronger focus on monetary transmission. #AskECB https://t.co/ExE9VFv1Vc

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: This summer the Governing Council of the ECB will decide whether to launch an investigation on the digital euro. After that, we will take the decision whether to launch a digital euro. The implementation would take several years. #AskECB https://t.co/m9Qs3nwXyX

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: The ECB aims at improving gender equality at all levels. Therefore we recently set new ambitious gender targets and have implemented numerous measures to increase diversity, including but not only related to gender equality. So please apply to the ECB! #AskECB https://t.co/iw285I7N0f

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: Our focus is on medium-term price stability. Current inflation developments show substantial volatility due to various one-off and temporary effects. We look through such short-term developments. #AskECB https://t.co/IzsClEO2tV

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: The HICP is calculated independently by Eurostat, not the ECB. It reflects actual consumption patterns. The prices of products from the supermarket do not reflect our full consumption basket, which also includes rents, services or electronic products. #AskECB https://t.co/oexz3Neon0

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: Asset purchases, low interest rates and bank refinancing operations support favourable financing conditions for households, firms and the government across the euro area. Without these measures, the outlook for growth and inflation would be worse. #AskECB https://t.co/vML9hw7GAj

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: Our introductory statements clearly state that our inflation aim is symmetric. Lowering the inflation aim would carry the risk of hitting the effective lower bound more frequently. The definition of price stability is discussed in our #strategyreview. #AskECB https://t.co/nlrWmSKJ4s

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: The inflation outlook is still well below our inflation aim of below but close to 2%. Monetary policy has to remain accommodative, including very low interest rates, to get the economy back on track, in line with our price stability mandate.  #AskECB https://t.co/v2qMVorprA

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: We expect a rebound of the economy in H2 2021 when containment measures are lifted & large parts of the population are vaccinated. But inflation is currently projected to remain low in the medium term, which justifies our highly accommodative stance. #AskECB https://t.co/Cm1iLyfGVg

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: Price changes of particular goods are not the same as general inflation. We are currently seeing price increases for some goods, like lumber, which may eventually be transmitted to consumer prices, depending on their weight in the consumption basket. #AskECB https://t.co/L18LFU6BgG

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: This is a misperception. As announced, we have significantly stepped up monthly net asset purchases under the PEPP. Due to reasons explained in a recent Twitter thread, this is not always visible in the weekly numbers. #AskECB https://t.co/8tE58ZHmlc

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: The ECB indeed has strict compliance rules, which limit the Governing Council members’ ability to hold and trade financial assets and require them to annually publish their financial holdings. #AskECB https://t.co/pgcsGZarp7

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: Since climate change affects price stability through physical & transition risks, we must take it into account under our primary mandate. Without prejudice to our price stability objective, we are also obliged to support general EU economic policies. #AskECB https://t.co/KKN1X0n0FV

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: We conduct our monetary policy on the basis of domestic economic conditions. But the international financial and economic system is highly integrated, which implies spillovers of monetary and fiscal policy, for example through global growth. #AskECB https://t.co/q1S1EqpdF5
If you want to find out more about the support for the euro, please refer to the latest Eurobarometer publication: https://t.co/Ii9jIzeJGa

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: The intrinsic value of the euro depends on its purchasing power. This is ensured by the ECB, which is independent & bound by its price stability mandate. The Eurobarometer shows record levels of support for the euro. Moreover the euro is legal tender. #AskECB https://t.co/Nvrrv2XSpg

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: The two-tier system has been successful in alleviating the side effects from negative interest rates for banks. If we were to observe risks to the bank-based monetary transmission from rising excess liquidity, the tiering multiplier could be adjusted. #AskECB https://t.co/gW3MLbis1D

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: EU membership is a key prerequisite. But there are exceptions. The euro is also used outside the European Union and beyond the European continent. You can find the full list and the specific reasons in our explainer: https://t.co/gw3GF1vK50 #AskECB https://t.co/C1NNYvrPUQ

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: The best measure of our credibility is price stability. The euro has been very stable since its inception. Due to disinflationary shocks, including severe crises, inflation has fallen below our aim. But it would be even lower without our measures. #AskECB https://t.co/KHvnR7SDvL

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: Our medium-term inflation aim is symmetric: we counter deviations to the upside and to the downside equally. We are currently reviewing our price stability objective in our #strategyreview, which will also address the question of overshooting.  #AskECB https://t.co/tuoztU2qYJ

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: The ECB’s primary mandate is price stability. Physical and transition risks from climate change may affect price stability, which should be taken into account in our monetary policy. How this can be done is discussed in our ongoing #strategyreview.  #AskECB https://t.co/xQFR7ceZcL

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: We will have to carefully manage the transition from the pandemic to the post-pandemic period. This may include a recalibration of our regular tools and will take into account the outcome of our monetary policy #strategyreview. #AskECB https://t.co/7wWIoCQaW7

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: Our monetary policy depends on economic conditions in the euro area and, in particular, on our medium-term inflation outlook. Business cycles vary across countries around the world, and so does monetary policy. #AskECB https://t.co/7swe83OhbC

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: Financial stability is a prerequisite for price stability and is related to our primary mandate. Therefore we carefully monitor the build-up of risks in the financial sector. Overvalued asset prices are one aspect, but we do not target asset prices. #AskECB https://t.co/gOpWhCUAde

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: Any policy measure is subject to side effects, monetary policy is no exception. We assess the proportionality of our measures by weighing their benefits and costs. Side effects like financial instability and inequality are important parts of that. #AskECB https://t.co/4fNnTaoPnV

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: Theoretically this depends on how real interest rates compare to real equilibrium rates. In practice this has to be judged in light of current and expected economic and inflation developments. The envelope may not be used in full or expanded as needed. #AskECB https://t.co/X4CgTLFOo6

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: Our inflation aim is defined over the medium term. This gives us flexibility to deal with supply-side shocks like temporary bottlenecks. Our current forecast suggests that inflation remains subdued over the projection horizon: https://t.co/Az8ogrFs6C #AskECB https://t.co/TbhJoZxdFW

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: PEPP was designed to deal with the pandemic and its duration is linked to the pandemic crisis phase. We are free to adjust any parameters of the programme at any point in time if required to fulfil our price stability mandate. #AskECB https://t.co/ED8CPsynkZ
If you want to find out more, have a look at our explainer on accountability: https://t.co/LcdshURfNR

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: We are accountable to all European citizens through the European Parliament. The President and other Executive Board members regularly participate in public hearings and explain the ECB’s policies to EU parliamentarians and the public.  #AskECB https://t.co/TBFizaewSd

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: Our inflation measure is based on the Harmonised Index of Consumer Prices, compiled independently by Eurostat on the basis of actual consumption behaviour. Perceived inflation can be different & individual inflation differs from the average. #AskECB https://t.co/yl533wpld1

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: The low profitability of euro area banks, also compared to global competitors, has been a reason for concern for quite some time. That’s why bank profitability is one of the key priorities for our banking supervisors in 2021:  https://t.co/wP33OKusFe #AskECB https://t.co/iGhpyc7BQI

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: The weekly change in the Eurosystem’s PEPP holdings (at amortised cost) at the beginning of April was affected by redemptions, the reduced number of trading & settlement days due to the Easter holidays and the quarter-end amortisation adjustment. #AskECB https://t.co/y2pzgg6aIO

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: Our targeted longer-term refinancing operations (TLTROs) have been crucial in supporting bank lending to households and firms. This has helped to avoid a credit crunch at the height of the pandemic. #AskECB https://t.co/AsLPudHCrE

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: Rising housing costs are a burden for many people and may give rise to financial stability risks. In our #strategyreview we discuss how to better capture housing costs in our inflation measure. But we do not target asset prices. #AskECB https://t.co/bIvFp5WsRg

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: Debt cancellation is not an option. It would constitute monetary financing and violate the Treaties. It would also call into question the ECB’s commitment to its price stability mandate and undermine the rule of law and the independence of the ECB. #AskECB https://t.co/FiIzfEoe7w

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: Preserving favourable financing conditions shifts the focus from quantities to prices – the conditions at which sovereigns, firms & households can receive funding. Monthly volumes vary, as we continue to buy flexibly according to market conditions. #AskECB https://t.co/rc6I3CFVGi
To find out more about the ECB’s economy-wide climate stress test, please refer to a recent article by our Vice President Luis de Guindos published on the ECB blog: https://t.co/TsnwqMkV84

🇪🇺@Isabel_Schnabel: The ECB is currently implementing an economy-wide climate stress test to analyse the vulnerability of firms and euro area banks to physical and transition risks. The potential impact on the portfolios of non-banks will also be considered. #AskECB https://t.co/glJiIvuP1d

Hello, this is @Isabel_Schnabel, Executive Board member at the ECB. I’m looking forward to answering your questions for the next 45 minutes or so. Join the conversation! #AskECB https://t.co/2V2m9uE7rZ
Letter from Andrea Enria, Chair of the Supervisory Board, to Mr Georgiou, MEP, on consumer protection https://t.co/mWgBkaALkF
Later today: Send us your questions using #AskECB and join the Twitter Q&A with Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel! https://t.co/c4cJCxLvht
Working Paper: Economic predictions with big data - The illusion of sparsity https://t.co/SvU0aKphf6

In his speech at the European Statistical Forum, Chief Economist Philip R. Lane discusses two challenges for macroeconomic statistics:

1⃣ Globalisation-related measurements 
2⃣ Data needs exposed by the pandemic crisis

Read his remarks https://t.co/yEz98PzKVy https://t.co/AMWaewzlcD

Panetta: By taking advantage of favourable financing conditions, fiscal authorities can achieve a full recovery. According to illustrative estimates, extra spending on productive investment of ~2.8% of GDP would allow to reconnect with the pre-crisis growth trend by 2022 5/5 https://t.co/ELBceLjf8X

Panetta: We should avoid withdrawing policy support until the output gap is closed and we see inflation sustainably back at 2%. We will have to maintain very favourable financing conditions well beyond the end of the pandemic 4/5

Panetta: Europe’s economic trajectory is in our hands. The ECB will continue to use its monetary autonomy to bring inflation back to our aim. In recent months, euro area yields have decoupled from those in the United States 3/5

Panetta: Global factors, especially commodity price shocks, can have sizeable effects on price developments. But globalisation has only marginal effects on trend inflation. The inflation process is still a domestic phenomenon that monetary policy can control 2/5
